PARATROOPERS RYAN SEES FORREST AND THE OTHERS DIE
SARGE TAKES A SHOT IN THE BACK. FALLS. MILLER AND THE O
ALL THE MEN PUSH, ALL EYES UP. WAITING FOR THE NEXT SHEL
ALL THE AMERICANS STAND AND FIRE
AN EIGHTY-EIGHT SHELL SCREAMS IN EXPLODES THIRTY YARDS LE
THE POTATO MASHERS EXPLODE KILLING FORREST AND THE OTHER
MILLER AND SARGE GET TO WADE
THEY HEAR THE SCREAM OF THE SHELL MILLER BARKS TO HIS MEN
IN THE BACK OF THE JEEP
THE MACHINE GUN SWINGS BACK TOWARD MILLER WADE JUMPS UP A
THEY MAKE IT TO THE TREES
THE TIGER'S MACHINE GUNS OPENS UP ON HIM.

THE LEAD LANDING CRAFT HITS THE BEACH

MILLER DIVES BACK TO COVER, BARELY MAKES IT, HIS BOOT HEA

ANOTHER EIGHTY-EIGHT SHELL LANDS EXPLODES THIRTY YARDS RI

SARGE STEPS INTO THE OPEN, INTENTIONALLY DRAWING THE GERM
THE MACHINE GUN SWINGS FROM MILLER
THE FIRST OF THE MORTAR SHELLS COME IN
UPHAM IS THROWN TO THE GROUND
A RUSH OF GERMANS ADVANCE, BLASTING AT THE BRIDGE.

THE MACHINE GUN SWINGS TOWARD WADE MILLER JUMPS UP AND SP

THE MOTORAMAN IS RIPPED TO BITS

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: CREDITS:  White lettering over a back background.  The THUNDEROUS SOUNDS OF A MASSIVE NAVAL BARRAGE are heard. power is astonishing.  It roars through the body, blows b the hair and rattles the ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ROAR OF NAVAL GUNS continues but now WE SEE THEM FIRI Huge fifteen inch guns.

dialogues.speaker: SWARM OF LANDING CRAFT
dialogues.text: Heads directly into a nightmare.  MASSIVE EXPLOSIONS from German artillery shells and mined obstacles tear apart th beach.  Hundreds of German machine guns, loaded with trac pour out a red snowstorm of bullets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: June 6, 1944

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HUNDREDS OF LANDING CRAFT Each holding thirty men, near the beaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the far end of the beach, a ninety- foot cliff.  Topped by bunkers. Ringed by fortified machine gun nests. A clear line-of-fire down the entire beach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make their way toward the base of the cliffs.  Running a gauntlet of explosions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STORY THE LEAD LANDING CRAFT Plows through the waves.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAMERA MOVES PAST THE FACES OF THE MEN
dialogues.text: Boys.  Most are eighteen or nineteen years old.  Tough. Well-trained.  Trying to block out the fury around them.

dialogues.speaker: A DIRECT HIT ON A NEARBY LANDING CRAFT
dialogues.text: A huge EXPLOSION of fuel, fire, metal and flesh.

dialogues.speaker: THE LEAD LANDING CRAFT
dialogues.text: The Motorman holds his course.  Shells EXPLODE around the FLAMING OIL BURNS on the water.  CANNON FIRE SMASHES into the bow.

dialogues.speaker: THE MOTORAMAN IS RIPPED TO BITS
dialogues.text: BLOOD AND FLESH shower the men behind him.  The mate take the controls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face covered with the remains of the motorman.  Starts to lose it. Begins to shudder and weep.  His name is DeLancey.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOYS AROUND HIM
dialogues.text: Do their best to stare straight ahead.  But the fear infe them.  It starts to spread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pushes through the men.  Puts himself in front of DeLancey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure is CAPTAIN JOHN MILLER.  Early thirties.  By f the oldest man on the craft.  Relaxed, battle-hardened, powerful, ignoring the hell around them.  He smiles, puts cigar in his mouth, strikes a match on the front of DeLan helmet and lights the cigar. DeLancey tries to look away but Miller grips him by the j and forces him to lock eyes.  Miller smiles.  DeLancey is terrified. Delancey Captain, are we all gonna die? Miller Hell no, two-thirds, tops. Delancey Oh, Jesus... Miller I want every one of you to look at the man on your left.  Now look at the man on your right.  Feel sorry for those to sons-of-bitches, they're going to get it, you're not going to get a scratch.  A few, including DeLancey, m thin smiles.  Miller releases his grip on DeLancey who mo his jaw as if to see if it's broken.  Miller pats him on cheek and moves on to the bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks over the gunwale at THE HELL IN FRONT OF THEM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It quivers in fear.  Miller glances around, sees that non of the men have noticed.  He stares at his hand as if it belongs to someone else.  It stops shaking.  He turns his eyes back to the objective.

dialogues.speaker: THE LEAD LANDING CRAFT HITS THE BEACH
dialogues.text: The six surviving boats alongside.

dialogues.speaker: EXPLOSIVE PROPELLED GRAPPLING HOOKS FIRE
dialogues.text: From the landing crafts.  Arc toward the top of the cliff

dialogues.speaker: THE LEAD CRAFT RAMP GOES DOWN
dialogues.text: A river of MACHINE GUN FIRE pours into the craft.  A doze men are INSTANTLY KILLED.  Among them, DeLancey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somehow survives.  Jumps into the breakers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVE, GODDAMN IT!  GO!  GO!  GO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE GERMANS On the edge of the cliff. Rain down MACHINE GUN FIRE and GRENADES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Struggle through the surf.  FIRING up as best they can.  Making for the base of the cliffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ignores the EXPLOSIONS and BULLETS. Uses hand signals and curt orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THERE!  THERE!  HOOKS THERE!  FIRE SQUAD, THOSE ROCKS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obey instantly.  Set the grappling hooks.  Take position.  Return fire.

dialogues.speaker: THE SOUNDS OF BATTLE
dialogues.text: Drown out most voices.  Except the SCREAMS OF THE WOUNDED AND DYING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what they have to do.  Start up the ropes.  Into the teeth of the German defenders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back-straps his Thompson sub-machine gun.  Starts climbing with the first group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Americans swarm up the ropes. Taking turns firing up at the Germans.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER SEES A STALLED CLIMBER
dialogues.text: A soft-faced boy.  Grabs him by the back of his collar. Roughly yanks him up.  Nearly choking him.  They boy clim on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An American private is HIT.  FALLS, taking two others with him.  All three land on the rocks below. Another way to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Less steep.  They leave the ropes. Free climb, scrambling up the rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joins half-a-dozen pinned down men. Others bottleneck behind them.  Miller scans the route and the defenders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sees an open gap.  Deadly.  Beyond is a protective overha With a clear line to the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the route.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller motions to six men huddled near him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take an instant to get ready.  Then SCRAMBLE into the gap.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER AND THE OTHERS
dialogues.text: Do their best to cover them.  POUR FIRE up at the Germans Bad angle.  No Germans are hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are CUT TO RIBBONS by MACHINE GUN FIRE.  All KILLED.  They fall to the rocks below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SARGE, mid-twenties, experienced, Miller's right arm and best friend, dives into the rocks next to Miller. Sarge That's a goddamned shooting gallery, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the only way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turns to the next half-dozen men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOU'RE NEXT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move to the head of the gap.  Miller moves for a better angle against the machine guns.  Calls to JACKSON, a tall, gangly Southern country boy, sharp-shooter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACKSON, PICK OFF A FEW OF THEM, WILL YOU?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heavy Southern accent) You betcha, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller signals others where to direct their cover fire. Turns to the second six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take deep breaths.  Head into the gap.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER AND OTHERS BLAST SURPRISING FIRE
dialogues.text: JACKSON, NAILS a pair of Germans.  MILLER CUTS DOWN two m SARGE gets one.  Not enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are RAKED BY MACHINE GUNS.  All are KILLED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turns, looking for the next six. His eyes fall on Sarge and REIBEN who is a cynical, sharp, New Yorker. Reiben smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heavy Brooklyn accent) Captain, can I put in for a transfer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, meet me at the top, we'll start the paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moves into place.  Sarge and Miller exchange a look.  They both see the madness of what they're doing.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER AND THE OTHERS
dialogues.text: OPEN UP on the Germans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rolls his eyes, takes a breath. Scrambles into the gap.  The other five right behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BULLETS EVERYWHERE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three are HIT.  Then another.  POTATO MASHER GRENADES bou down.  EXPLODE below. THE GERMAN MACHINE GUN swings toward Sarge and Reiben.  M sees them about to get it...  MILLER STEPS OUT INTO THE O A perfect target.  Captain's bars glinting.  FIRING.  TRY TO DRAW THE GERMAN FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: THE GERMAN MACHINE GUNNER
dialogues.text: SEES MILLER STANDING IN THE OPEN.  Too much to pass up. swings the machine gun away from Sarge and Reiben, toward Miller. A ROW OF GERMAN BULLETS approaches Miller...he's an insta from death.

dialogues.speaker: SARGE AND REIBEN DIVE
dialogues.text: Under the overhang to safety.

dialogues.speaker: IS BLOWN OFF.
dialogues.text: UNDER THE OVERHANG Sarge and Reiben untangle themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be Goddamned!  I'm not dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarge hollers back to Miller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAPTAIN, IF YOUR MOTHER SAW YOU DO THAT, SHE'D BE VERY UPSET!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I THOUGHT YOU WERE MY MOTHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick smiles.  MILLER AND HIS RANGERS lean out and FIRE. HIT more Germans. SARGE AND REIBEN run up the path, under the overhang.  St near the top.  Pull pins on grenades.  Count.  Both throw long, arcing over the crest, perfectly aimed. THE TWO GRENADES EXPLODE. Putt out the two worst machine gun nests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crosses the gap.  His men follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Americans swarm over the top. FIRING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO DOZEN GERMANS FIRE BACK as they retreat. Abandoning the perimeter defense of the bunkers.  The Ger are CUT DOWN. MILLER motions to WADE, a small, wide-eyed, demolition ma who's struggling under the weight of half-a dozen satchel charges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Wade, your turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade Captain, I love it when you say that. Miller, Sarge, Reiben and Jackson cover Wade as he races the first of three bunkers.  Dodging bullets from inside. Wade tosses a SATCHEL CHARGE into a gun port.  A HUGE, MU EXPLOSION, rocks the bunker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Survey the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell were you doing?  Drawing fire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worked, didn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tryin' to get yourself killed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't need to, the Krauts go that covered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarge shakes his head at Miller, then he looks over the c at the scores of men, their shattered, burning bodies cov the rocks and the beach below.  He's clearly affected. Miller coldly glances at the dead and wounded.  Then he m on, leading his surviving men toward the two remaining Ge bunkers.  The SOUNDS OF BIG GUNS and MACHINE GUNS FIRE surround him.  DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND OF CLATTERING MACHINE GUN FIRE SEGUES TO that o CLATTERING TYPEWRITERS.  A huge government building stand in the heart of Washington, D.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WAR DEPARTMENT WASHINGTON, D.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very busy.  A dozen, somber military clerks work behind d quickly and efficiently.  No small talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Older than the others, sad-eyed, adds a sheet of paper to a large pile in his out-box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An outgoing telegram.  It reads: "We regret to inform you...killed in action...heroic service..."  This is the paperwork of death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulls out a file.  Reads.  Finds something troubling.  Quickly shuffles through some other papers.  Finds what he's looking for.  Rises from his desk and hurries out of the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen through the glass wall.  The clerk speaks to a YOUNG LIEUTENANT who is visibly shaken by what he is being told He motions to the clerk to follow and he strides out of t office with the clerk on his heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, seen through a glass wall.  The Young Lieutenant s to a YOUNG CAPTAIN who, like the Lieutenant is clearly bothered by what he's being told.  The Captain takes the papers from the Young Lieutenant and strides out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A busy office.  Aides and secretaries scurry about.  The walls and tables are covered with maps of Normandy and co deployment charts.  A ONE-ARMED COLONEL with a chest full ribbons pours himself another cup of coffee.  He clearly hasn't slept in a long time.  The Young Captain, his staf officer, walks in. Young captain Colonel, I've got something you should know about. One-armed colonel Yes? Young captain Two brothers died in Normandy.  One at Omah Beach, the other at Utah.  Last week in Guam a third brot was killed in action.  All three telegrams went out this morning.  Their mother in Iowa is getting all three teleg this afternoon. The life drains from the Colonel.  Others in the room hea and freeze. One-armed colonel Oh, Jesus. Young captain There's more.  There's a fourth brother.  T youngest.  He parachuted in with the Hundred-and-First Airborne the night before the invasion.  He's on the fron One-armed colonel Is he alive? Young captain We don't know. The Colonel regains his bearings.  Stands and motions cur to the Captain.  One-armed colonel Come with me. The Colonel regains his bearings.  Stands and motions cur to the Captain. One-armed colonel Come with me. The Colonel strides from the room with the Captain on his heels.  The aides and secretaries watch them go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black car drives along a dirt road, a cloud of dust ris behind.  Passing through an endless expanse of ripening c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A whit farmhouse.  A barn.  A stand of trees.  Cornfields far as the eye can see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tire swing.  A bushel basket nailed to the barn over a dirt basketball court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sits empty.  Moves slightly.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE GLASS OF THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Four American flag decals.  Each one, a man in service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steps out.  Around sixty.  Her face shows the lines of a life of hard work and mother hood.  A good woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wipes her hands on her apron and looks out across the fields.  Far in the distance she sees the dust rising beh the black car. She watches the car get closer, then sees it turn toward house.  She starts to grow uneasy. As the black car approaches, her breath comes hard.  She reaches out and steadies herself on the porch post. The car pulls up to the house.  She sees three men get ou one wearing a clerical collar.  The first of her tears co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another busy office filled with aides and secretaries. GENERAL GEORGE MARSHALL, Army Chief of Staff, stands next his conference table, reading the Ryan brother' files.  H a-dozen subordinates, among them the one-armed Colonel an the Young Captain, wait.  General Marshall puts down the file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Goddamn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One-armed colonel All four of them were in the same compa in the 29th Infantry but we split them up after the Sulli brothers died on the Juneau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any contact with the fourth brother, James?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One-armed colonel No, sir.  He was dropped about thirty m inland, near Ramelle.  That's still deep behind German li General Marshall hardens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if he's alive, we're going to send someone to get him the hell out of there.  That's just what the General's staff wanted to hear.

dialogues.speaker: NEAR CONSTANT MORTAR EXPLOSIONS. HEAVY MACHINE GUN FIRE.
dialogues.text: Miller's Ranger company is pinned down by a superior forc of German troops.  The Americans hug the bottoms of the craters, FIRING BACK as best they can.  BIG GUNS THUNDER the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Normandy 1300 hours June 9

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trailed by a RADIOMAN, dashes through the fire and dives into a sludge- filled crater.  He surfaces, sees Sarge and Reiben, and reels from a horrific smell.  Their conversation is repeatedly broken by FIRING And DUCKING GERMAN FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ!  What the hell are we swimming in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fertilizer, Captain, I think we're in a cranberry bog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the frying pan, into the fucking latrine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at the bright side, the Krauts sure as hell don't want to advance and hold this cesspool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller barks to his RADIOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get Fire Control, we need some artillery...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Radioman Trying, sir. MORE EXPLOSIONS.  They all duck.  Reiben's worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, what if they send some other company into Caen ahead of us while we're pinned down here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, we're the only Rangers this side of the continent, we've got to be first into Caen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I care.  Don't you know what Caen's famous for, Sarge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frogs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lingerie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE GERMAN FIRE diminishes for an instant.  Miller, Sarge and Reiben immediately rise and POUR FIRE at the German positions.  GERMAN MACHINE GUN FIRE RESPONDS and they duc down again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you ever heard of employee discounts?  My uncle sells shoes, gets twenty-five percent off everything in the line, got a closet filled with the best looking shoes you ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just picture some French number been spending all day, every day, making cream-colored, shear-body negligees with gentle-lift silk cups and gathered empire waists, what the hell you think she wears at night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reiben, how the hell do you know so much about lingerie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lingerie is my life, sir.  My mother's got a shop in Brooklyn, I grew up in it, from the time I could crawl, we carry Caen lingerie, it's the best there is, it's all I been thinking about since the invasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another pause in the German shelling.  Reiben rises and B HIS B.A.R, then ducks as the GERMANS RETURN FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a war on, good chance they're not still making lingerie in Caen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Captain, they'll always make lingerie, it's one of the three basic needs of man -- food, shelter, silk teddies.  Miller Dream on, private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy to, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Radioman Captain, I've got Command, they want you back at H.Q., right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe the war's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MORTAR SHELL EXPLODES VERY CLOSE.  After the debris sto falling, Sarge and Reiben rise, spitting out sludge.  Rei looks dubiously at Miller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Radioman) Stay at it until you get fire control. (to Sarge) Keep 'em down, wait for the navy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller waits for a pause in the MORTAR BARRAGE, then scra out of the crater and takes off in a crouch-run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaos.  Under fire.  INTERMITTENT MORTARS, SOME BIG GERMA SHELLS and fairly close SMALL ARMS FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Runs over the broken ground and makes it to the sandbagged H.Q.  He stumbles down the make-shift stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sand and dirt falls with the closest of the EXPLOSIONS wh continue through the scene.  Miller salutes a Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller, Company B, Second Rangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Go on in. Miller goes deeper into the H.Q. bunker where he finds a dozen officers with as many aides, runners and radiomen. Very busy.  A field map dominates the center of the small space. The men in the room note Miller, a few nod to him respectfully.  He's clearly someone special. COLONEL SAM ANDERSON is in command, talking on a field-ph He's about fifty, firm and steady, the calm at the eye of the storm.  He sees Miller and motions for him to wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into field-phone) ...I understand your problem, but if we don't get those tanks off-loaded by 0600, we're going to have an entire division up at Caen with its ass hanging out of its pants...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LIEUTENANT steps up to Miller and hands him a sheet of paper. Lieutenant Captain, here's your company address list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant For letters to the families of your killed-in- action. Miller hands the list back to the Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find a chaplain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into field-phone) ...alright, let me know when.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson hangs up, speaks to an AIDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have the Second and Third Regiments hold at St. Michel until we get those tanks.  Aide Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Anderson turns to Miller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sector four is secured, we put out the last three German one-fifty-fives, found them about two miles in from Ponte du Hoc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Resistance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A company, Wehrmacht, no artillery, we took twenty-three prisoners, turned them over to intelligence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Casualties?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourty-four, twenty one dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An instant of SILENCE, all hear, none look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't want to give up those one-fifty-fives, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a hard assignment, that's why you got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are your men now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinned down, a mile east of here, waiting for some help from the navy guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sending Simpson to take over for you, the division is going to Caen, you're not coming with us, I have something else for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a Private James Ryan who parachuted in with the Hundred-and- First near Ramelle.  I want you to take a squad up there.  If he's alive, bring him back to the beach for debarkation.  Take whoever you need, you've got your pick of the company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A private, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the last of four brothers, the other three were killed in action. This is straight from the Chief of Staff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, sir...I...I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spit it out, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Respectfully, sir, sending men all the way up to Ramelle to save one private doesn't make a fucking, goddamned bit of sense. (beat) Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other officers freeze, listening without turning.  Co Anderson glares at Miller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think just because you hold the Congressional Medal of Honor, you can say any damn thing you please to your superior officers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller considers the question, then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, more or less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Anderson looks as if he's about to bit Miller's h off, then he smiles, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, I'll give you that. Continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The numbers don't make sense, sir. His brothers are dead, that's too bad, but they're out of the equation. Sending men up there is bleeding heart crapola from three thousand miles away.  One private is simply not worth a squad.  Colonel anderson This one is.  He's worth a lot more than that.  Which is why I'm sending you, you're the best field officer there is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller Shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes and no, sir, what about Morgan? Fine officer, regular church goer, writes poetry, he might like a mission like this. (beat) And he's taller than me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Anderson listens with amused tolerance, but it's time to get back to business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough, Captain, you have your orders.  Major Thomas will fill you in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller knows when to back off.  He salutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller and Colonel Anderson exchange a private look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller joins Major Thomas at one of the smaller map table Colonel Anderson watches Miller for an instant, then noti the other officers in the tent watching.  A glare and the go back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MASSIVE BARRAGE of fifteen-inch shells BLASTS from the deck of the enormous ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HUGE EXPLOSIONS.  The big naval shells SLAM into the Germ position on the far side of the cranberry bog crater fiel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller's Ranger company ducks and covers.  The BARRAGE SUBSIDES.  The Rangers rise, FIRING, leap-frogging from crater to crater, advancing against the remaining Germans who return SMALL ARMS FIRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crouch-runs and dives into a crater with Sarge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put on your traveling shoes, Sarge, we're heading out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish.  You and I are taking a squad up to Ramelle on a public relations mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You?  Leading a squad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some private up there lost three brothers, got a ticket home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the company?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simpson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simpson?  Jesus Christ on a fucking pogo stick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want Reiben on B.A.R; Jackson with his sniper rifle; Beasley, demolition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beasley's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Wade.  Translators?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fresh out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Talbot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty minutes ago.  Miller Damn, I'll go see if I can find another one.  You get Reiben, Jackson and Wade, meet me at transport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wait for a lull in the firing, then scramble out of crater and crouch-run in opposite directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just in from the beaches.  DISTANT ARTILLERY AND EXPLOSIO Nothing close.  Dust.  Confusion.  Vehicles of every sort moving out.  Tanks, half-tracks, troop trucks.  In the mi of the mess, a cigar-chewing SUPPLY SERGEANT works at a m shift desk made out of crate.  He yells at a PRIVATE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GET THOSE GODDAMNED HALF-TRACKS OUT OF THERE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Private They're blocked in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEN UNBLOCK 'EM!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SARGE< REIBEN, JACKSON AND WADE Wait nearby.  Reiben is beside himself, pacing, muttering The others are relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strides through the chaos, avoiding the passing vehicles.  He sees his men and walks toward them.  Reiben hurries up to Miller, pleading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, sir, you can't take me to Ramelle, I gotta go to Caen, sir, please, I told you, they make Caen lingerie there, it's beautiful, it's the best there is, it's...oh, please, sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, I need a B.A.R. man, you're the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperate) No, I'm not, Kaback is, honest.  Or what about Faulkner?  Or that little guy with the glasses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me, you're the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whimpering) But, sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller jerks his head for his men to follow and he stride off toward the Supply Sergeant's table.  Sarge falls in n to Miller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get a translator, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a line on one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaos.  Vehicles THUNDERING by.  The Supply Sergeant juggles runners and paperwork.  Miller steps up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant, I need a truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir, fresh out of trucks, how 'bout a '38 Ford Roadster, hard-top, red with black interior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White-walls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No white-walls, sir, there's a war on. (to the Private) NOT THERE, YOU GODDAMNED IDIOT, OVER THERE! (to Miller) I can't help you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A half-track, anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir.  Division is using everything on wheels to get up to Caen. (notices Miller's shoulder patch) How come you guys aren't going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller ignores the question.  He spies a jeep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about that jeep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's General Gavin's.  His lap dog told me if anyone breathes on it, I'll get busted and if anyone so much as touches it with their little finger, I'll get court marshaled. If you were to take it, they'd shoot me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cap'n, does that mean we got to walk all the way up to Ramelle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's at Ramelle beside a lot of Germans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A paratrooper named Ryan.  He's going home, if he's alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senator's son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, three brothers of his were killed in action.  Command wants him out of there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Supply Sergeant grunts as if punched in the belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn...I got a couple brothers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller looks at him, noting his reaction coldly.  The Sup Sergeant shifts his eyes toward General Gavin's jeep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller and his men drive off, fast, in General Gavin's je Sarge is at the wheel, weaving and bouncing through the b of men and vehicles.  Miller rides shotgun.  Reiben, Jack and Wade are crammed in the back. The SUPPLY SERGEANT Watches them go.  Behind him, GENERAL GAVIN, pure piss and vinegar, strides up, trailed by his huge staff.  He looks around for his jeep, comes up empty

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERGEANT, WHERE THE HELL IS MY GODDAMNED JEEP!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Supply Sergeant puffs his cigar with a smile and turn to take his lumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller and his men weave through the chaos of the America staging area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to make one stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller points the way for Sarge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller and his men skid to a stop in front of a perfectly white, taut-lined tent.  A steady stream of ROARING vehic and CHATTERING men move out around them.  DISTANT GUNS RU SPORADIC MEDIUM-DISTANCE EXPLOSIONS BOOM.  Miller hops ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strides into the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three bookish corporals hover over map tables like studio nerds the day before finals.  They're breaking down and gridding field maps and covering them in plasticine.  Ted detailed work. One of them is TIM UPHAM, a thin, twenty-four year old, patrician with gentle, thoughtful eyes behind his thick glasses.  He nervously jumps at the sound of a VERY DISTA EXPLOSION, then he forces himself to concentrate on his w Miller strides in.  Miller I'm looking for Corporal Upham Upham raises his eyes from his map and re-focuses. Upham Sir, I'm Upham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand you speak French and German.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have an accent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham A slight one in French.  My German is clean.  It ha touch of the Bavarian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, you've been re-assigned to me, we're going to Ramelle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham knows enough geography to know what that means. Upham Uh, sir, there are Germans up at Ramelle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham Lots of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a problem with that, Corporal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham Sir, I've never been in combat.  I make maps.  I translate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a translator, all mine have been killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham But, sir, I haven't held a gun since basic training

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll come back to you.  Get your gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham hesitates. Upham Sir, may I bring my typewriter? Miller looks at him closely, not sure if he's joking. Upham I'm writing a book and I... Miller's expression gives him his answer. Upham Uh, how about a pencil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller shoos him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham scurries away.  Miller sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller and his men peel out, now with Upham crammed with others in the back of the jeep.  As they drive off, the C CRANES UP to reveal the vast tableau of the biggest invas in military history. The scope of the operation is stunning.  The beach is cov with mountains of supplies.  A steady stream of vehicles winds up the dunes.  Hundreds of barrage balloons, anchor by heavy steel cables, hover over the entire scene.  Off- shore, a massive Mulberry port is under construction, wor swarming over it like ants.  Beyond that, thousands of sh and boats of every type and description.  The smoke of hundreds of fires rises on the horizon.  EXPLOSIONS, some distant, some close, BOOM and RUMBLE. It's an awesome, breathtaking sight.  Miller and his tiny band of men, weave their way through the middle of it, speeding away from the beach, heading inland, leaving the bulk of the American Army behind.  Ext. french road - day Miller and his men drive fast passing American vehicles a infantrymen moving forward.  The sides of the road are littered with the debris of burning German vehicles, aban equipment, bodies. Sarge drives.  Miller reads a map.  Upham, cradling a pri M-1 rifle, is all eyes and ears.  Jackson and Wade calmly take in the view.  Reiben checks out the close quarters i the back of the jeep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, can I ask you a question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Reiben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you planning on putting Private Ryan, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller doesn't raise his eyes from the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) It's just that it's kind of crowded back here, I was wondering if you're expecting to have more room on the way back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller points out a turn to Sarge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarge makes the turn.  Miller folds up the map and pocket it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we've got a straight shot, due north, to Ramelle, twenty-six miles, two villages between here and there, St. Mere, then Bernay.  We'll take the jeep as far as we can, then go on on foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We in radio contact with anybody up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody put the wrong crystals in every one of the Hundred-and-First's radios the night before the drop, not one of them works.  We're going in blind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I usually like surprises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we likely to run into?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fucking mess, two maybe three Kraut divisions, no fronts, no lines, the drops were completely fouled up, we've got little pockets of paratroopers all over the place, trying to hang on.  Command says we hold St. Mere, but north of that, it's all Krauts.  Even if Ryan's where he's supposed to be, he's more than likely dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell of a mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep, hell of a mission.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BACK OF THE JEEP
dialogues.text: Upham avidly takes in everything.  He notices Reiben star at him, grows nervous under his look and offers a hopeful smile. Upham Hi.  So, uh, you're all Rangers? Reiben, Jackson and Wade look at Upham as if he were an insect. Upham I'm Upham. (pointing at his corporal's stripes) Ignore these, please, I know all that breaks down in comb Their jaws drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Wade) You want to shoot him, or should I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade It's not my turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (politely) Jackson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, no, last time I shot a corporal, Cap'n Miller near bit my head off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham reacts to the metion of Miller's name. Upham Miller?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want anybody to shoot him, that's an order.  He speaks French and his German has a touch of the Bavarian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham Sir, are you Captain John Miller? Miller sighs, he knows what's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...who won the Congressional Medal of Hon...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham's words are frozen in his throat by the warning gla of Miller's men.  Miller himself remains relaxed but ston faced. No one speaks for a few seconds, then the moment passes a if it had never happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, I gotta tell you, the irony of this mission is fucking killing me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, how so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should be on my way to Caen, sir. It's like Beethoven, the guy's one of the greatest composers ever lived and he goes deaf.  Go figure, I mean, who'd he piss off?  And here I am, the Beethoven of ladies foundation garments, one step away from Caen, the center of the known lingerie universe and instead, I'm going to Ramelle to save some fucking private who's probably already dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's to be a bright side, look for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, you know what Ramelle is famous for?  Cheese.  The rest of the company is going to Caen and we're going to the goddamned cheese capital of France.  There is no bright side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's always a bright side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm listening, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I, for one, like cheese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade pipes up cheerfully. Wade Hell, I don't mind going to Ramelle, as long as ther something up there for me to blow up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're a happy idiot.

dialogues.speaker: BOTTLENECK OF AMERICAN VEHICLES
dialogues.text: A LIEUTENANT is roadmaster.  Miller calls to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the road up to St. Mere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Bad, sir.  There're some eighty-eights hiding somewhere, knocking the hell out of our traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody getting through?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant The lucky ones. Miller nods to Sarge who floors it.  They take off, spray gravel behind them.  Ext. St. Mere Road - day The jeep ba down the road, fast.  The road is pock-marked with crater They pass the wreckage of a pair of American jeeps.  Dire hits.  Sarge swerves around them without slowing.

dialogues.speaker: AN AMERICAN TROOP TRUCK SMOLDERS
dialogues.text: On the side of the road, surrounded by the charred bodies a dozen American troops.  It's a nightmare vision.  Upham grows weak at the sight.  Miller takes note of Upham's reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men bounce up and down like stuffed animals, doing their best to not be thrown out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, this is better than Coney Island!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bounces Reiben up and slams his back down on his shovel.  He HOLLERS IN PAIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just trying to make room for Ryan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reiben shoots Miller a smile and shifts his belt, moving shovel from under his bruised ass.

dialogues.speaker: THEY ROUND A BEND
dialogues.text: See a long, straight stretch of road.  Half-a-dozen burni obliterated American vehicles.  A gauntlet to run.

dialogues.speaker: AN EIGHTY-EIGHT SHELL SCREAMS IN
dialogues.text: Lands right behind them.  BLOWS A NEW CRATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweetly) Sarge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SARGE FLOORS IT.  Everyone hangs on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty yards ahead of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Directs Sarge off the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've got the road zeroed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yanks the wheel, driving the jeep off the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off the shoulder.  Nearly throwing everyone out.  Somehow they hang on. The jeep tears along the rutted field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not slowing down.  Trying to avoid the biggest ruts and bumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on their side.  Showers them with debris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ!

dialogues.speaker: MILLER SCANS THE TERRAIN
dialogues.text: Sees a cluster of buildings about half-a-mile ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've got a hell of a spotter somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even closer.  The jeep's PEPPERED WITH SHRAPNEL.  They BARREL THROUGH the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S-curves, Sarge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turns shallow curves without slowing down.

dialogues.speaker: SUDDENLY SEES A CRATER
dialogues.text: Tries to avoid it.  Too late.  Brakes.  PLOWS into overtu earth.  STOPS SHORT.

dialogues.speaker: REIBEN, UPHAM, WADE AND JACKSON
dialogues.text: THROWN from the jeep.  TUMBLE into the dirt.  Not hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on.  Stay in the jeep but are battered.  All stunned.  MILLER Is first to regain his bearings.  Jumps up.  Checks out the jeep.  Undamaged. Deep in the soft dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarge!  Reverse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarge puts his head back on and throws the jeep into gear The wheels spin.  Miller throws his shoulder into the jee Yells to the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COME ON!  YOU WANNA WALK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reiben, Wade, Jackson, Upham screw their heads back on.  Shoulder into the jeep.  Push for all they're worth. The WHEELS STILL SPIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the only one who does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, they got us zeroed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham is very nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's bracketing, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all ignore him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know about bracketing.  I read about it.  The next one is going to land right on us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FORWARD!  FORWARD! (beat) NOW REVERSE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarge SLAMS THE JEEP INTO REVERSE.  Rocks it.  SLAMS IT B INTO FORWARD.  Makes progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Captain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Captain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bit more progress.  It's almost out.

dialogues.speaker: THEY ALL PUSH LIKE MANIACS
dialogues.text: Knowing the shell is coming any second.  Upham is beside himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweetly) Oh, Captain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jeep rocks back in, deeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHIT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instantly take off.  Away from the jeep.  As fast as they can.

dialogues.speaker: THE SHELL SCREAMS IN
dialogues.text: The men hit the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OBLITERATING THE JEEP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barely out of the BLAST PERIMETER. STUNNED by the concussion.  SHOWERED with dirt, rock and debris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is first up.  Sarge and the men struggle to their feet.  Hear MORE INCOMING.  Miller grabs Upham by the collar and pulls him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HERE COME THE MORTARS!

dialogues.speaker: THEY ALL TAKE OFF
dialogues.text: Running as fast as they can.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIRST OF THE MORTAR SHELLS COME IN
dialogues.text: The eighty-eight is big, with pauses spaces between.  But there must be a dozen mortars firing.  The shells are alm constant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The six Americans run madly, in zig- zag patterns through the gauntlet of MORTAR EXPLOSIONS.  BOOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOOM, BOOM, BOOM

dialogues.speaker: UPHAM IS THROWN TO THE GROUND
dialogues.text: Miller yanks him up.  Half-drags him to the edge of the f

dialogues.speaker: THEY MAKE IT TO THE TREES
dialogues.text: Keep running.  Through the bushes and brambles.  Thirty y in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE MEN ALL STOP Panting.  Struggling to catch their breath. Check their body parts.  Everything's there. They have their weapons, most of their gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reiben looks back through the trees at THE JEEP, which is nothing more than a burning carcass.  He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Gavin is going to be very irritated at you, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stands on the edge of the woods, almost in a trance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sssssh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller, far away, quickly shifts his eyes and ears from position to position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarge, maps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarge quickly opens up the map case.  The men are dead si frozen in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two eighty-eights, just under two- and-a-half miles, that way, vector from the jeep, through those two trees at the base of the hill.  The mortars came from behind that rise, there, four of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarge quickly starts vectoring on the map.  Miller snaps of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade instantly starts cranking it up.  Upham is amazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can tell all that, just by the sound, sire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not all.  There were nine gunners on the eighty-eights, one had a broken heel on his boot, two had bratwurst for supper last night, one of them is named Fritz, the other, Hans, maybe, I don't know, it's hard to tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corporal, you have just seen one of Captain Miller's many God-given talents.  If, by some miracle, you survive, you will witness many more of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarge finished vectoring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it, sir.  We gonna go take care of those eighty-eights?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what we're here for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re. radio) I've got command, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller takes the handset from Wade and the map from Sarge

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into radio) This is Baker Charley One, fire mark, sector three, foxtrot quadrant, four- three by baker-three.  Two eighty- eights.  Tell our boys to come in low from the east in case the Krauts have ack-ack.  Good hunting.  Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VOICE ON THE RADIO SIGNS OFF through the static.  Wade packs up the radio.  Miller folds up the map.  Jackson Si wouldn't take us but a minute to put out them eighty-eigh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right, Captain, it might be kind of dangerous for those flyboys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell that to Private James Ryan. We've got our orders.  Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller heads off without pausing or looking back.  The re of the men don't like it, but they follow.  Upham trails, amazed at Miller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller walks point.  His men follow warily.  Upham falls alongside Reiben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham smiles lamely and moves on to Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You writin' a book or somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade overhears and smiles at Upham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Wade, that's spelled, W-A-D-E, I'm small but wiry, with piercing, steel-gray eyes, and a rough-hewn but handsome face, I'm from Colorado, my father's a mining engineer, don't you take notes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Demolition, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since I was nine years old.  They got a lot of explosives around mines. Me and my little brother could get into any warehouse you ever saw. Damn, we had fun!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Jackson.  I'm from West Fork, Tennessee.  My pappy's a preacher. Him and his two brothers got a ministry, The Blessed Church of the Wandering Gospel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In West Fork?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the back of a nineteen and thirty- one stretch Hudson with a big ole' trailer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't make jokes about things of, or related to, the preaching of the Holy Gospel, including the ministerial calling of my family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they travel around from place to place and preach?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got us a tent, forty-two feet across, eighteen feet at center, hundred-and-ten foldin' chairs. Circuit's eleven towns, covers all 'a Hasset County and most 'a Weller County.  I expect that upon completion of my military service I will be joinin' said ministry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the Captain?  Where's he from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all shake their heads.  Miller's out of earshot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You figure that out, you got yourself one nice prize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over three hundred bucks, last I heard.  Wade Company's got a pool, five bucks gets you in, whoever guesses where the Captain's from and what he did as a civilian gets it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole kit and caboodle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But everybody's heard of him, he won the Congressional Medal of Honor, he saved a dozen men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody must know where he's from, what he did for a living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody probably does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just ask him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain prefers not to discuss certain aspects of his life, in particular, everything up to and including his enlistment in the United States Army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been with him since Anzio.  I'm closer to him that I am to my own brother but I don't even know what state he's from.  Somewhere in the Northeast as near as I can figure. I don't even have a clue what he did for a living as civilian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reiben shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's gonna win the money for the simple reason that the Captain never was a civilian.  They assembled him at O.C.S. out of spare body parts from dead G.I.'s.  I know this for a fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively) You got somethin' against the Cap'n?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, no.  I think he's the best officer in the whole goddamned army, bar none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all nod in assent, no argument there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got that right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller walks on ahead, unaware of their conversation.  Up watches Miller, with even more curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller and his men walk along a hedgerow that parallels a country cow path.  They're staying close to the cover of brush.  Miller walks tall now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, my feet are most uncomfortable.  If I'd 'a known we was gonna have to walk all the way to Ramelle, I never would 'a volunteered for this here mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't volunteer, Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I most likely would have, sir, had I been given the opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we find Ryan and he's still alive, that son-of-a-bitch is gonna carry this goddamned B.A.R. back to the beach for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Army life is too dang easy, my feet have gone soft.  Back home, we go out squirrel huntin', I walk forever and a day and then some, don't even raise a blister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what a B.A.R. weighs? Nineteen and a half pounds, not counting ammo. (re. ammo bandoleers) And you think these things are comfortable?  They may look good but they weigh twelve pounds each, that's thirty-six pounds, right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what?  I've got three satchel charges, six gammon grenades, a dozen- and-a-half pineapples, and all my regular gear.  You don't hear me complaining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because, as I have pointed out on numerous occasions, you are a happy idiot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I just happen to take the Captain's advice and look at the bright side of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's easy, it runs in my family, take my grandfather, for example...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ, now we gotta listen to that grandfather thing again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I was saying, before I was so rudely interrupted, my grandfather got old, as grandfathers tend to do. He needed someone to take care of him.  We move around all the time, going from one mine to another, so we had to put him in a home.  Nice enough place but kind of depressing. But not for Granddad.  He just convinced himself he was on a cruise ship, going to Tahiti, he had his own cabin, first class, with room service.  It just so happened that the weather was always lousy, so he never bothered to go up on deck. Happiest guy you ever saw until the day he died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think he really believed it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows?  It worked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, you convince yourself you got a pack full of feathers and goddamned Private James Ryan can carry my fucking gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reiben, you can be very unpleasant to be around sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want unpleasant?  Just wait, I can do much better than this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at Upham, you don't hear him complaining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham, feeling bold and a bit naughty, decides to give it shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, as a matter of fact, I was just thinking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men roll their eyes, expecting the worst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) That I'm so fucking tired of this goddamned walking, I'd pay a thousand dollars to see that bastard Ryan crawl on his belly over an acre of broken glass to hear my great-aunt Martha fart through a field-phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, he's a natural!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham, are you sure you've never been in combat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham wiggles with pride.  Upham Positive, sir, I'm certa I'd remember. Miller eyes Upham respectfully and nods to the men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cap'n, my feet are most uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller smiles, situation normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small town has been reduced to rubble and is still an a battlefield.  HEAVY SMALL ARMS FIRE.  GRENADE AND MORTAR EXPLOSIONS.  MEDIUM ARTILLERY BEYOND.  American soldiers crouch in doorways, FIRING at well-placed Germans. Some French civilians dash across a street.  A man and a couple of women, one carrying a child.  They make it acro and disappear into the remains of a building. Miller runs up and flattens himself against a wall at a corner.  Sarge and the other men follow in leap-frog, spr out down the block behind him. Miller glances around the corner, taking a quick mental picture of a GATHERING OF G.I.'s crouching in the cover o an alley across the street and down the block.  They are CAPTAIN HAMILL, about Miller's age, and HIS MEN. As Miller ducks back behind the corner, A GERMAN BULLET SMASHES into the bricks where his head was an instant bef Miller motions Jackson across first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson gathers himself, takes off.  GERMAN BULLETS BLAST kicking up the cobblestone behind him.  Jackson zig-zags makes it to the cover of the far side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dang!  That was close!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller nods to Upham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham, scared shitless, doesn't move.  Miller speaks to h very gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zig-zag, change your pace a couple times, you'll be alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham's frozen.  He can barely breathe.  Miller sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm going to draw fire for you. (sternly) But if I do, you goddamned well better go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham nods.  Miller gathers himself, takes a deep breath. CLOSE SHOT:  MILLER'S HAND quivers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks to Upham

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham nods, still terrified.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER STEPS INTO THE OPEN
dialogues.text: Stands motionless, presenting himself to the German snipe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham runs. A GERMAN BULLET HITS THE BRICKS NEAR MILLER. He doesn't budge. UPHAM TEARS ACROSS THE STREET very, very fast. REIBEN watches Upham run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, that guy can move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GERMAN BULLET WHIZZES PAST Miller's ear.  UPHAM gets to the far side. MILLER DUCKS BACK around the corner.  Reiben and Wade don even react to what Miller has just done.  Sarge is pissed He shakes his head at Miller, like an irritated parent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath so only Miller can hear) Damn fool. (beat) Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, he's fast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glances at Sarge, speaks to Reiben) Glad of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other side of the street, crouches in a doorway with Jackson. Upham is a bit in shock, less from the nearness of the bullets than from what Miller just did for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DASHES across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERMAN BULLETS TRAIL HIM, shattering the cobblestones, in behind him. HE MAKES IT across.  Calls back to Sarge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring 'em over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UPHAM, tries to thank Miller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller ignores him, motions to Sarge, Reiben and Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ducks out of the doorway and crouch- runs down the block.  He passes a:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the line of fire.  A dozen dead American soldiers lined up on the ground.  The battered, bloody bodies, only partially covered by ponchos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some badly wounded G.I.'s are being treated next to the d Blood puddles have spread out onto the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sees the dead and wounded, shows no reaction.  Runs to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Hamill and his men are bunched there, out of the line of fire. He's sending off a squad to continue their door-to-door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain hamill Fundamentals, short runs, double up at the corners, one man close, one man wide.  Be careful.  Go. The squad takes off.  Captain Hamill sees Miller.  The tw captains glance at the bars on their shoulders, then spea familiarly. Captain hamill How was the road in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had a jeep until a few hours ago, a nice one, it had a cute little flag with a couple of stars on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain hamill Oh, what a shame. One by one, Miller's men join them in the alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We called in a strike on the eighty- eights that took it out, but it's the Kraut spotter that counts, wherever the hell that bastard is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Hamill points across a wide field toward a distan chateau that has a private chapel with a fifty-foot steep Captain hamill That's where your boy is.  We've been tryi to get him since this morning.  He killed two of my men t to get close enough for a shot.  Miller eyes the distant steeple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson steps up.  Miller points to the steeple.  Jackson knows what he's supposed to do.  He puts down his M-1 and takes off the long, zippered, leather sheath, strapped to his back. He spits a massive bullet of tobacco juice, then calmly a methodically unzips his leather case and pulls out a very unusual, long-barrel, rifle. Miller and his men give him some room.  Hamill and his me along with Upham, watch curiously. Jackson opens a two-foot tripod with a flick of his wrist sits down and carefully attaches the rifle to it.  Then h takes a scope from a narrow wooden box and mounts it.  He adjusts the eye-piece and clicks in the bolt-action.  Uph is fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson pulls back the bolt and loads a single, over-size shell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-ought-six, Norton long-barrel with dual-groove, parallel rifling, elevated three-glass scope and a single-throw hammer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Army gave you that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be a hell a shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not where I come from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson sights on a tree about a thousand yards away and FIRES.  Evaluates.  Calibrates the scope.  He re-loads. Jackson FIRES AGAIN.  Evaluates.  Perfect.  He wipes the dirt and sweat from his forehead, puts his eye to the sig and waits, absolutely motionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must be four thousand yards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without taking his eye from the scope) Forty-two-hundred, I figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take account of the wind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson doesn't dignify that with an answer but he looks back with an expression that clearly says, "What are you, some kind of fucking idiot?" Reiben puts himself between Upham and Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (put-on Southern accent) Dang right, he take 'count of the wind, ain't ya'll ever heard a Kentucky windage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson keeps his eye to the scope and his finger on the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reiben, how many time I got to tell you, I'm from Tennessee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got squirrels there, too, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson FIRES.  Waits.  A tiny smile.  He starts taking a the rifle.  A very impressed Captain Hamill barks to his radioman.  Captain Hamill Get a hold of Command, tell the the St. Mere road is open. The Radioman cranks up his radio.  Captain Hamill turns t Miller. Captain Hamill How far back is the rest of division?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very far, they're not coming this way, they're going to take Caen first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Hamill Goddamn it, I was afraid of that.  We're i lot of trouble up here, and it's gonna get worse before i gets better.  How many men did you bring?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five, but we not staying, we're on our way to Ramelle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain hamill Shit, are you the guys going up to find Pr Ryan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you know about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain hamill Command radioed, wanted to know if he came with the early wounded or dead. Several of CAPTAIN HAMILL'S MEN, among them a GENTLE-FACE PRIVATE, prick up their ears at the mention of Private Ry Captain hamill We're supposed to tell you, they intercept a German transmission after you left.  The Krauts have tw companies on their way to Ramelle to take back that bridg they'll be there sometime late tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Hamill If Ryan's alive, you'd better get him the hell out of there before those Krauts show up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do we get out of here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain hamill You don't, until tonight, we're hemmed in real tight.  After dark you try to slip out to the east. you tip-toe, stay off the main roads and roll a few seven you've got a fair chance of making it up to Ramelle by tomorrow night. Miller processes the information.  Captain Hamill shakes head. Captain hamill Tough, huh?  Three brothers? Miller shrugs. Captain hamill We sure as hell could use your help here, I understand what you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain hamill Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain hamill I mean it.  Find him.  Get him home. Miller is a bit taken aback by Captain Hamill's forceful sincerity.  Then he shakes it off and motions to his men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's find someplace to hole up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller nods to Captain Hamill, then, as he moves to the h of the alley, Miller passes Upham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I'm sorry about what happened, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) It was nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you could have gotten killed and I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Like I said, it was nothing. (to the men) Don't bunch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes off, crouch-running back down the block.  Upham watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see what he did, back there? He stepped right into the open, so I could get across.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, that was no big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like hell they can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade's right, it's some kind of scientific, magnetic thing, I can't explain it, but I've seen it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all have, he's got nine lives, or he's bulletproof, or some damn thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are equal parts joking and admiring.  Sarge is neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's bulletproof.  No one. (beat) C'mon, stay low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarge takes off after Miller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller and his men are bivouaced in the middle of the rui of a medieval church.  Miller, settled into a comfortable spot in the debris, eating his K-rations, looks very rela Reiben paces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, could you please explain the math of this mission to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, what do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir, in purely arithmetic terms, since when does six equal one?  What's the sense in risking six guys to save one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ours is not to reason why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind, don't worry, we'll pick up this kid, high-tail it back to division, everything'll work out fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd much rather die in Caen than Ramelle, sir.  It's a personal thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reiben, there's a fairly good chance you're not going to die at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy for you to say, sir. (beat) Fucking James Ryan, I'd like to wring his fucking neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Reiben, think of the poor bastard's mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I got a mother.  Jackson, you got a mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last I knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade, Sarge, Corporal Insect, all of us, hell, I'll bet even the Captain has a mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller smiles.  Reiben eyes him and reconsiders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe not the Captain, but the rest of us have mothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have orders, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I have an opinion on this matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems to me, Cap'n, this mission is a serious misallocation of valuable military resources.  Miller Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir, by my way a thinkin' I am a finely made instrument of warfare. What I mean by that is, if you was to put me with this here sniper rifle anywhere up to and includin' one mile from Adolf Hitler, with a clear line of sight, war's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reiben, I want you to listen closely to Jackson.  This is the way to gripe. Jackson, continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  It seems to me, sir, that the entire resources of the United States Army oughta be dedicated to one thing and one thing only, and that is to put me and this here weapon on a rooftop, smack-dab in the middle of Berlin, Germany.  Now I ain't one to question decisions made up on high, sir, but it seems to me that saving one private, no matter how grievous the losses of his family, is a waste of my God-given talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I don't mind this mission, sir, as long as there's something up at Ramelle for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finishing Wade's sentence) ...for you to blow up, yeah, yeah, we heard that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just here to keep a bunch of numb-nuts, including one certain, frequently suicidal, tempter-of-fate, from getting themselves killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reiben eyes Miller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what about you, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
