dialogues.text: Slowly, Miller's men turn to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you say, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I teach English at Addley High School in Addley, Pennsylvania.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll be goddamned, I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like hell, you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, what about our deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I changed my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I coach the baseball team, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kiddin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all sit in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that cruise ship Wade's grandfather was on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all nod, except Ryan who doesn't know what Miller's talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I wonder if his cabin is still available?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not where I am.  Miller No? Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in a dressing room with Mrs. Rachel Troubowitz, our super's wife. She's an easy forty-four, double E, but I've convinced her she's a thirty- eight D and I'm watching her try and squeeze herself into a side-stay, silk-ribboned, three-panel girdle with s Helf-lift brassiere. (smiles) She's having a devil of a time, getting into that thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all share Reiben's dream for a moment.  Then Jackson smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?  I'm walking with my hound, Lucy, it's about an hour 'fore sunrise and we're out huntin' coon.  I got me a flask of pure Kentucky mash whiskey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson, how many times I got to tell you, you're from Tennessee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am, but I like imported whiskey. So there I am and I hear the biggest ole' coon you ever did hear, 'a rustlin' right there in front of me. That ole' boy comes right out of the brush, I got a clear shot and he knows he's 'bout to meet his maker. I aim, I got my finger tight on the trigger and then I just smile and say to that ole' coon, go on, now, you get out 'a here.  Then I sit down on a hollow log and take me a right long pull a' that mash whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I kind of like Wade's idea about the cruise ship.  I've never been to Tahiti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller smiles.  He knows exactly where he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in my backyard, lying in my hammock, with my arm around my wife, listening for the sound of breaking glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say what, Cap'n?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, I've got the best house in all of Addley.  It's not the biggest house, but it's got the best location, right next to the junior high baseball field.  The garage windows face left field.  The guy who owned the house before me had these heavy screen S put over them.  The first thing I did when I bought the place was take off those screens.  Two-hundred-twenty- two yards from home plate to my garage windows.  It takes a hell of a junior high kid to hit a ball that far.  I look at my garage windows as a Motivator and a way to scout the kids coming up, the ones who are going to give us a shot at the state championship.  I lay there in my hammock and every time I hear the sound of breaking glass, I know we're one step closer to winning it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't that get kind of expensive, Cap'n?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's worth it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To each, his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all silent for a moment.  Then Miller turns to Ry

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about you, James?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm home, playing basketball with my brothers, it's evenin' time, we're trying' to get in a few more points before it's too dark to see the ball. That's where I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all nod.  Miller tears off a piece of bread and pass it to Ryan who tears off a bit and passes it on.  They al eat in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First light.  Lovely.  Dew shimmers.  A ground fog drifts A SOUND.  Louder.  And louder.  A GERMAN TIGER TANK RUMBL toward the village.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All are awake.  At their positions.  Waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hears the FAINT DISTANT RUMBLE OF THE TANK.  Barely has time to react. Sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here they come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIRES a burst.  Germans drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIRES a burst.  More Germans drop.

dialogues.speaker: THE GERMANS KEEP COMING
dialogues.text: Lots of them.  Moving from cover to cover.  FIRING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manning the forward machine gun. Way out front.  Sees that he's going to be cut off.  He grabs the hot gun.  The barrel burns into his flesh. He ignores the pain and RUNS BACK toward the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE DIVES over the sandbags.  barely makes it.  TRAILED BY BULLETS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take positions near the bridge. Moving in.  FIRING.  Overwhelming. They're everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Break through the perimeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RYAN SHOOTS one.  GRAPPLES with the other two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sees Ryan.  Races over.  SHOOTS one German.  STABS the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RYAN FALLS BACK.  Stunned, unhurt. REIBEN only gives him a quick look.  Gets to the MACHINE GUN. OPENS UP against the Germans who are still coming.  FIRES LONG BURST.  Germans drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIRES again.  More Germans drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take positions in the building near the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start working their way to the tops of the nearby buildings. Making their way along the riverbanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forward.  Reiben FIRING.  Ryan feeding the ammo belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MORE AMMO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hears that.  Doesn't hesitate.  He grabs a pair of ammo boxes.  RUNS toward Reiben and Ryan.

dialogues.speaker: SEVERAL GERMANS ZERO UPHAM
dialogues.text: OPEN UP on him. BULLETS TRAIL UPHAM.  He's outrunning them.  Almost there

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TAKES HALF-A-DOZEN SLUGS.  Torn apart. Stumbles the final few steps to the machine gun nest.  Falls on the sandbags, giving Reiben and Ryan the ammo.  UPHAM'S DEAD.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN STUNNED.
dialogues.text: For just a micro-second.  No time.  Grabs the ammo.  REIB FIRING.  Ryan clips the new ammo belt onto the tail of th one almost out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continues FIRING.  CUTTING DOWN the advancing Germans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knows what that means.  He hears the RUMBLE OF THE TANKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHTEN IT UP!  HERE THEY COME!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immediately grab the machine gun and ammo and race back to the rear nest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then RYAN AND MILLER converge at the eighty-eight.  THE F TANK APPEARS Huge.  Terrifying.  Clanking.  Trailed by tw German infantry platoons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the bridgekeeper's hut.  Picking off German soldiers who follow the tank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GERMAN INFANTRYMAN SPOTS JACKSON.  Hollers into the tan voice-tube.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stops.  Grinds its gears.  Turning it's turret towards the bridgekeepers hut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACKSON!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knows what's coming but he holds his position, continuing to pick off German soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BRIDGEKEEPER'S HUT AND JACKSON ARE OBLITERATED IN THE EXPLOSION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEE JACKSON DIE.  A bare moment to react.  Then, they turn their attention back to the eighty-eight. Frantically turning the aiming cranks. Lowering the barrel to point blank.

dialogues.speaker: TANK AGAINST EIGHTY-EIGHT.
dialogues.text: Which can fire first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Win the race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLAST THE LEAD TANK DESTROY IT IN A SHOWER OF METAL AND FLAMES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quickly reload the eighty-eight. FIRE AGAIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoves the FINAL SHELL into the breech of the eighty-eight.  Pats Ryan on the back.  Grabs a SATCHEL CHARGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUNS down the bridge.  Right toward the two advancing tan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIRES THE EIGHTY-EIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Races through the debris.  Trailed by BULLETS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the machine gun.  Covers Miller. Keeping most of the German infantry down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RYAN jumps behind the second machine gun.  Opens up.  Hel to cover Miller.

dialogues.speaker: THE LAST GERMAN TANK
dialogues.text: Turret spins.  Turning toward the fast approaching Miller Ready to blow him to bits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is almost there.  He arms the satchel charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throws the satchel charge under the tank.  Rolls off the edge of the bridge.  Lands on the embankment below.

dialogues.speaker: THE LAST TIGER TANK EXPLODES
dialogues.text: MILLER, RYAN, REIBEN continue FIRING. Almost out of ammo. MILLER SCRAMBLING UP THE EMBANKMENT, back onto the bridge hears something over the SOUNDS OF FIRING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLD IT!  HOLD IT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan and Reiben cease firing.  Now they hear it, too. A RUMBLE, DEEPER AND MORE OMINOUS than any they've heard yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More tanks...  Ryan Lot's of them The fear on their faces turns to resignation.  They know that they are dead men.  They settle into their positions, and prepare to fire and die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wait.  The RUMBLE GETS LOUDER AND LOUDER. THEN MILLER'S FACE STARTS TO CHANGE...a hint...of a smile...then a real smile... AN AMERICAN SHERMAN TANK APPEARS from over the rise.  The ANOTHER...AND ANOTHER...AND ANOTHER...

dialogues.speaker: MILLER, REIBEN AND RYAN
dialogues.text: Stand there, stunned, watching tank after tank appear, al with scores of heavily-armed American soldiers. They keep coming and coming.  American tanks, with wave a wave of U.S. infantrymen, looking for targets.  They find few among the departing Germans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run onto the bridge and start to secure the position.  A SERGEANT and a few of HIS MEN look around, curiously eyeing Miller, Reiben and Ryan, battered and bloody, standing among the bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAJOR strides up. Major Report, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller, Company B, Second Rangers, that's Private Richard Reiben and that's Private James Ryan, Hundred- and-First Airborne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sergeant and several other soldiers overhear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the soldiers speaks quietly to another. Soldier That's him, that's Ryan. The Major puts his hand on Ryan's shoulder. Major Command is looking for you, son.  You're going home Ryan looks up, tired.  He nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: American tanks and hundreds of fresh troops stream down t road and over the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: MILLER, RYAN AND REIBEN
dialogues.text: Watch.  In a small area, cleared of the debris, the bodie of Jackson, Upham, Sarge, Forrest and the other paratroop are laid out, neatly, respectfully, covered. Miller and Reiben stay protectively close to Ryan, as if they don't want to risk him being bumped into or run over any of the advancing troops or vehicles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walks to the bodies.  He kneels down next to Sarge and looks at him for a long moment.  Then, with a steady hand, he takes one of Sarge's two dog-tags.  Then he does the same to Jackson and Upham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REIBEN AND RYAN watch silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stands and walks back to Reiben and Ryan.  He hands the dog-tags to Ryan who grips them tightly and nods in thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller takes a last look at the bridge and the bodies, th he shoulders his gear.  Miller Let's move out. Reiben and Ryan gather up their gear.  They walk with Mil down the road, away from the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three dirty, bloodied, tired men walk down the road, ignored by the fresh troops marching in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham and Jackson, what were they like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upham?  Good kid, smart, he was writing a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and he was fast, too, ran the 220 in twenty-four-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson was from West Fork, Tennessee, he was going to be a preacher, his father and uncles have a traveling ministry out of the back of a stretch Hudson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Sarge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarge? (beat) He was the best friend I ever had. (smiles) Lemme tell you about Sarge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk on, disappearing in the distance among the hund and hundreds of American soldiers who are marching down t road and over the bridge. Fade out.
